awd_titl_txt: Life-history and behavioral consequences of competition between solitary and pair-bonded primate conspecifics
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to establish, develop, and maintain social relationships is important in many species, including humans. There are positive effects of social bonds on health, mortality, and reproduction. In this project, the researchers will examine behavioral, demographic and genetic factors that may contribute to the ability of an individual to establish successful social relationships. Focusing on a non-human primate model in which both father and mother provide care to their young, the researchers will study interactions between reproducing pair-bonded adults and solitary non-reproducing ones. This research will contribute to a better understanding of social relationships, including mating and parenting relationships, in pair-living, monogamous groups. The team will train nine undergraduate students, two Ph.D. students and one postdoctoral researcher from groups underrepresented in STEM fields. International collaborations with researchers in Argentina will be strengthened, and the investigators will expand efforts to foster the development of the biological anthropology discipline in Latin America. At the national level, outreach activities will include working with programs involving underrepresented minority high-school and undergraduate students in research (STARS program at the Yale Peabody Museum) and creating a public series of presentations based on their work for topics regularly covered in animal behavior and biological anthropology courses. 

This research project occurs within the Owl Monkey Project of Argentina, an international research program to advance knowledge and theory about the evolution of pair-bonding, monogamy, and paternal care. In this new study, a team of researchers, undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs will collect demographic and genetic data from individuals in 60 groups of owl monkeys. The investigators will study solitary individuals who have left their natal group but have not yet pair-bonded, as well as pair-bonded adults. The solitary individuals need to enter a group to reproduce, which generates intense competition between solitary and pair-bonded adults. Data collected as part of this project will be used to evaluate how competition between solitary floaters and pair-bonded adults influences infant development and survival, natal dispersal patterns, pair-bond formation and stability, and mating patterns. In addition, because this primate species shows very little physical difference between males and females, but intense competition in both sexes, these data will be valuable for understanding the evolution of sex-specific morphologies and behaviors. The project will therefore make theoretical and empirical contributions to a number of concepts that are central to biological anthropology and evolutionary biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Owl monkeys are one of the few pair-living, pair-bonded monogamous primates in the world. They live in groups where there is only one adult male and one adult female who mate monogamously; they only mate with each other. Pairs are in an affiliative relationship that is durable and stable. They travel, eat, sleep, and provide care to their infants together; in fact, the fathers provide almost all care besides nursing. When the infants grow and become sexually mature, they disperse and leave their natal group. During the last decade, the Owl Monkey Project of the Argentinean Chaco characterized in detail what happens after they disperse. The implications of this life stage for the rest of their lives are profound. After leaving their natal groups, these young adults “float” solitarily among the territories of other established pairs, attempting to evict a resident same-sex adult and take his, or her, reproductive position in the group. The consequences for evicted adults are dire; they seldom reproduce again, instead, they often die after a brief period. It follows that the pair-living and pair-bonded individuals experience intense competition from solitary floaters. What are the individual, group and population consequences of that competition?

By focusing on a non-human primate, it is possible to study the biological underpinnings associated with the ability to establish, develop, and maintain pair bonded social relationships between individuals free from the cultural trappings that are associated with similar studies in humans; in doing so the project contributes to understanding the evolution of pairbonding and monogamy. Thus, the Owl Monkey Project offered a unique situation to examine the consequences of the competition between male and female solitary floaters and resident reproducing adults on individual fitness, group dynamics, population biology. Specifically, an international team of researchers, postdocs and students evaluated the hypothesis that the competition between solitary floaters and pairs influences pair mates, as well as their offspring. The team combined behavioral, life-history, and genetic data to evaluate how the presence of a new adult in a group influences infant development and survival, natal dispersal patterns, the formation and stability of pairs, and their mating patterns.

In the forests of Formosa Province in Argentina, researchers monitored and collected data from over 50 different groups of wild owl monkeys. For genetic analyses, they collected 900 samples of feces which allowed the genetic identification of 250 individuals. Preliminary analyses revealed that the presence of new reproducing adults in the groups is associated with lower infant survival and early ages at dispersal. Furthermore, while both male and female young owl monkeys disperse and leave their natal groups, females disperse slightly farther away than males. Once fully analyzed, the findings will certainly have an impact on the theoretical models proposed to explain the evolution of sociality in primates and other mammals, particularly regarding the role that solitary floaters, virtually ignored in the literature, have on the evolution of pair-bonded and monogamous social and mating systems.

The project funded educational opportunities of 14 undergraduate and five Ph.D. students, and one postdoctoral fellow. The PI continued collaborations with the Universidad Nacional de Formosa and established new ones with the national universities of Misiones and Buenos Aires. In the US, samples were shared for collaborative publications reporting comparative analyses of primate microbiomes and primate genomic diversity. Results were presented at professional meetings, invited lectures and the Frontiers In Social Evolution International Remote Seminar series and also shared through variosus public outlets. There were presentations by the PI in the Lunch Break Science of the Leakey Foundation, the Yale Alumni Association and the McGovern Lecture of the American Association for the Advance of Science. The life of owl monkeys was also communicated to worldwide audiences in the Life Matters and Night on Earth documentaries by the BBC and Netflix respectively.  

The Owl Monkey Project, started in 1996, is the longest and most interdisciplinary project on any mammal of Argentina. The demographic, life-history and, specially, all the genetic data collected during this last study further positions it as one of the most comprehensive studies of primates in the world, and the only one of pair-living primates for which detailed information on a subpopulation of floaters is available. The project has had multiplying effects on the conservation of the Humid Gran Chaco ecosystem and its fauna (which includes howler monkeys, peccaries, tapirs, armadillos and many other endemic and/or endangered species). The project has generated jobs, promoted tourism, trained local human resources and communicated to both the local, national and international community the importance of scientific research.
